info.game_comments:
Jared Hall game 3.
First game of Season 30.
New set and opening graphics.

double_jeopardy_round: MASTERPIECES FROM THE NORTON SIMON MUSEUM

(1, 1).clue: He wasn't an alien visitor, but Felix Baumgartner did come from 24 miles up when he landed in this Southwest state in 2012

(2, 1).clue: I'm hotter than Brad Pitt!  I can beat Lebron one-on-one!  I'm the king of the world!  I'm suffering from "delusions of" this

(3, 1).clue: A more original pole dance?  This West Indies dance uses a progressively lowered bar

(4, 1).clue: "The Wind Done Gone" parodies this classic published 65 years earlier

(5, 1).clue: This word meant a tall hat or a tall guy before it meant a towering glass building

(1, 2).clue: In May 2013 hearts rejoiced when 3 women missing for nearly a decade escaped to freedom in this city

(2, 2).clue: This 3-word nickname for the Republicans dates to 1876

(3, 2).clue: Music for this dance of Bohemian origin is heard here; an-a 1, an-a 2...

(4, 2).clue: The original by this author inspired "The Soddit: Or, Let's Cash in Again"

(5, 2).clue: At Princeton Michelle Obama lived in Pyne Hall, one of these residences

(1, 3).clue: This leaker of NSA secrets had quite a layover, 5 weeks, in Moscow's Sheremetyevo Airport

(2, 3).clue: This term applied to international auto races was originally the name of a 19th c. Paris horse race

(3, 3).clue: "Scaramouche, Scaramouche, will you do" this lively South American dance in triple time?

(4, 3).clue: A self-help parody tells us "Vampires Are from Venus, Werewolves Are from" here

(5, 3).clue: One difference between a wigwam & this other Native American dwelling is that a wigwam is domed & the other is a conical tent

(1, 4).clue: In August 2013 ex-president Pervez Musharraf of this country was charged with the murder of Benazir Bhutto

(2, 4).clue: Louis Lapostolle created this orange-flavored liqueur in 1880

(3, 4).clue: Marlon Brando actually does (or attempts) this title dance at the end of a 1972 film

(4, 4).clue: Kantkiss is the heroine of the Harvard Lampoon parody titled these, what you get when lunch is late

(5, 4).clue: This term for ancient arenas like the Colosseum comes from Greek words meaning "viewing on both sides"

(1, 5).clue: In 2013 this Boston-area town was in the news as a marathon bombing suspect was captured there

(2, 5).clue: As part of their education, young men of fortune used to visit Europe's major sights on a trip known as this

(3, 5).clue: Also a haircut style, it's the R&B-based state dance of South Carolina

(4, 5).clue: This parody of "Goodnight Moon" is a reminder to power down, especially a device kids love

(5, 5).clue: If you've been invited to a friend's dacha for the weekend, it's probably in this country

(3, 1).clue: Chronologically, he was the first who fits the category

(4, 1).clue: Hausa, one of the Chadic languages, is spoken by some 50 million people on this continent

(6, 1).clue: (Alex gives the clue from the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena, CA.)  For many years, art historians believed that this famous Dutch painter had painted an engaging portrait of his son, Titus; not so; the identity of the boy is a mystery

(1, 2).clue: Innate intelligence not from education, or the title of a 1776 pamphlet

(3, 2).clue: He was preceded & succeeded as president by the same man

(4, 2).clue: With more than 70 million speakers, Javanese is spoken by more than a quarter of the people of this country

(6, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew gives the clue from the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena, CA.)  The influence of African sculpture can be seen on this Italian's painting style--a long, oval face with simplified features atop an elongated neck

(1, 3).clue: Campus chapters of this fraternity founded in 1776 invite straight-A students to join

(4, 3).clue: This branch of the Indo-European languages includes Scottish Gaelic & Manx

(6, 3).clue: (Alex gives the clue from the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena, CA.)  Modern viewers are really entranced by "Little Dancer, Age Fourteen", but when this artist first exhibited this work in 1881, it was cast in wax, not in bronze as it is now, & the public was a little bit put off by the realism of real clothing & a wig of human hair

(1, 4).clue: Puzzles & brainteasers challenge your intelligence in this magazine founded in 1977

(3, 4).clue: For refusing to shine the boots of a British officer as a child, he got a saber across the face

(4, 4).clue: Most of the book of Daniel was written in this Semitic language, still spoken in isolated Mideast villages

(6, 4).clue: (Alex gives the clue from the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena, CA.)  The bronze "King and Queen" exemplify the biomorphic shapes that were preferred by this Brit, whom some people regard as the greatest sculptor of the 20th century

(1, 5).clue: An early fictional example of A.I., he was a humanoid computer from the planet Colu who battled Superman

(3, 5).clue: He whipped 2 former presidents in the same election by an electoral score of 435-88-8

(4, 5).clue: The boys from Siracusa are among the 5 million speakers of this island tongue

(6, 5).clue: (Alex gives the clue from the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena, CA.)  The design of the garden here at the Norton Simon Museum was inspired by Claude Monet's own garden in this French village; both feature water lilies floating on a pond that reflects the sky

(0, 0).clue: Funds provided by his widow were used to set up a literary charity called Old Possum's Practical Trust
